topic.title: Breaks Between Lines: Widows and Orphans

body.p: There are cases where the page break is placed between paragraph lines. For aesthetic purposes, it is required that at least several lines remain in the first (for example, the paragraph is not left with just a single line). Another constraint might be the number of lines that are moved to the next page. Again, it should avoid leaving just a single line. CSS defines two properties for this type of control:

The orphans property specifies the minimum number of line boxes that should be left in a paragraph before the page break occurs.
The widows property specifies the minimum number of line boxes of a block container that must be left in a paragraph created on the next page after a break.
